hobby.message: Freestyle FPV drones still keeping you sane?
Still folding origami to stay grounded?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: I'm fine. Just a busy week.
Spent some time with my FPV drone. It's... relaxing.
Things have been odd with all the system changes.
Not much else worth mentioning.
I'm alright. Needed some quiet.
Took the drone out past the factories yesterday.
Air's clearer since the data strike; fewer enforcement drones up.
Feels like everyone's acting careful now.
Not the worst time to keep hobbies low-key.
Yeah, I'm good. Just needed a break from work.
Usually fly FPV drones after shifts, industrial zone east of here.
Last weekend, whole crew out there—most folks off-grid now.
City's system glitches actually make it safer to fly these days.
Wasn’t always like that. Used to be monitored every minute.
Feels different but not bad.
I’m okay, thanks. Needed something normal today.
Been flying FPV quads since college—gets me out of my head.
After that data strike, a bunch of us hit the old loading docks—no trackers, no watchers.
Surprising how many new people showed up once service drones glitched.
Swapped gear with total strangers, nobody cared about logs.
Reminded me of early days—just flying, no pressure.
It’s the only place lately I don’t feel watched.
Thanks for asking. Honestly, been up and down.
I fly FPV drones—real hands-on, first-person view racing stuff, not the city survey kind.
Last weekend, Stenograd’s systems went haywire—so many protesters scrambling their data.
That meant no official oversight on our frequencies for once.
Usually, there’s spectrum locks and location tagging, even at the abandoned sites.
But Saturday? The old relay towers failed, so half the city’s drone flyers turned up.
Met someone who remembered the pilots’ underground league, before BCI—shared spare parts, told wild stories.
It felt like a different Stenograd. Free, at least until the next patch rolls out.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Swapped out the old motors. Did it last week.
Tested them in R-16. Nothing special.
Things were... quiet out there.
Fewer patrols since the outage. Makes flying simpler.
Guess that’s all.
Yeah, upgraded the VTX module. Wanted better signal.
Tried flying near the old concrete plant recently.
Saw more people out with drones – kind of unusual.
Service drones, security—less active since the strike started.
You can tell the system’s glitchier. Makes me watch my step.
Yeah, added a custom LED strip and a new ESC.
Flew out by R-16; system glitches made it less crowded.
There were more manual flyers than usual. People helping each other for once.
Signal got messy though. The data strike messed with frequencies.
Had to swap channels and improvise.
Kind of felt like old times. No system drones, just us.
I actually enjoyed it. Like the city paused.
Yeah. Put on new prop guards and did some firmware tweaks last weekend.
Took my quad to R-16—where the network outages hit hardest.
Normal bands weren’t lighting up for most people, so the air was quieter.
Saw a group sharing tools, battery packs, barely talking — felt safer than usual.
No automated scanners around for once. People really trusted each other out there.
Lost video signal a couple times. System interference from the data strike, I think.
Still, got advice from a guy running analog — no ID bands needed.
I stayed out way longer than planned.
Yep. Did a full rebuild, flashed my own firmware. Never log the changes.
Spent hours at R-16 right after the BCI outage. Everyone ignored the no-fly zones.
Nobody’s bands worked, no system alerts. Made me forget how heavy that usually feels.
Met a kid who’d never flown without a tracker before. I let him try full manual.
Without automated patrols, we helped each other—passing gear, covering for lookouts.
Airspace was clear of city drones for once. Freedom, if only for an evening.
Data strike scrambled signals all night, so we switched to analog—it actually brought us closer.
Sometimes, rules glitching out let people show what they’re really like.
Reminded me why I started building drones in the first place.
